titleStmt.title: Toward a Comprehensive and Potentially Cross-Cultural Model of Why People Engage in Collective Action: A Quantitative Research Synthesis of Four Motivations and Structural Constraints

analytic.title: Toward a Comprehensive and Potentially Cross-Cultural Model of Why People Engage in Collective Action: A Quantitative Research Synthesis of Four Motivations and Structural Constraints

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Sociopsychological theorizing and research on collective action (e.g., social protests) has mushroomed over the last decade, studying a wide variety of groups, contexts, and cultures. Through a quantitative research synthesis of four motivations for collective action (1,235 effects from 403 samples; total N = 123,707), we summarize and synthesize this body of research into the dual chamber model, a comprehensive and potentially cross-cultural model of collective action. We aim to replicate previous meta-analytic conclusions (about identity, injustice, and efficacy) and break new theoretical ground by (a) integrating a fourth motivation (morality) into the very heart of the psychology of collective action, (b) extending these four motivations to advantaged group members acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged, and (c) integrating theoretically relevant structural (i.e., cultural and other contextual) constraints. Results substantiated the dual chamber model as all four motivations yielded unique, positive, medium-sized effects and interrelationships were positive (particularly among morality and identity, conceptualized as the dual chambers of the protester's beating heart). Meta-analytic structural equation modeling supported the added value of including morality. Moreover, findings confirmed that the strongest specific motivations were emotional injustice and politicized identification, while newly adding moral conviction to that list. Finally, the four motivations extended to advantaged group members acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged, while only the identity motivation was constrained by theoretically relevant cultural dimensions and values (e.g., collectivism and hierarchy). We discuss the implications and limitations of the dual chamber model for integrative theorizing, innovative research, and the practice of collective action.

div.head: Public Significance Statement
div.p: This broad research synthesis finds that individuals' engagement in collective action (e.g., protests, demonstrations) is uniquely predicted by their identity, moral, injustice, and efficacy motivations. Despite small cultural constraints, the four motivations predicted collective action across the globe and applied to disadvantaged group members as well as advantaged group members acting in solidarity with them. Our findings offer specific recommendations for practitioners toward targeting these four motivations for collective action.

Why do people around the globe participate in social protests and demonstrations? The psychological literature on such manifestations of collective action often defines such actions as those enacted by psychological group members who seek to improve the conditions of their disadvantaged group (Wright et al., 1990;p. 995), with recent work extending this definition to include members from other groups acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged (e.g., van Zomeren, 2013). 1 As such, collective action occurs based on a psychologically relevant social identity, defined by Tajfel (1978) as the knowledge that one is a member of a particular group, together with the emotional and value significance attached to this group membership. This definition paints a portrait of the protester in which their social identity reflects the protester's beating heart, suggesting a common psychology behind collective action, be it whether people act for Black Lives Matter or the climate, protest against war or COVID restrictions, or seek to collectively change laws or see their government toppled.

We move beyond this portrait of the protester by formulating and testing a more comprehensive and potentially cross-cultural model of collective action. This model integrates moral motivations for collective action (i.e., those based on values, moral principles, or ideology; e.g., Van Stekelenburg et al., 2009) with established motivations for collective action (van Zomeren et al., 2008), and with theoretically relevant cultural constraints 2 on these motivations (e.g., collectivism, hierarchy; Hofstede, 2010;Schwartz, 2008;Oyserman et al., 2002). The dual chamber model of collective action (visualized in Figure 1) portrays the protester's beating heart as reflecting the dual chambers of social identity and morality, which, to continue this metaphor, collaborate to oxygenate the blood pumped around the body to foster the emotional experience of group-based injustice (e.g., anger) and the belief in the efficacy of the group, both of which help individuals understand and deal with the group's situation and motivate collective action.

Conceptually, the integration of morality 3 into the very heart of the psychology of collective action is both fundamental and formative. This is because although the theoretical focus in this literature has been on social identity as binding individuals into groups that obligate individuals to act on its behalf (e.g., Stürmer & Simon, 2004;van Zomeren, 2013), morality often serves these very same functions (e.g., Ellemers, 2017;Haidt, 2007;Rai & Fiske, 2011). For instance, strong individual moral beliefs can define and create emerging group identities that bring people together (e.g., Fridays for Future), just as strong existing group identities can push specific group norms into the moral domain (e.g., Greenpeace seeking to ban whale hunting by framing it as immoral). The dual chamber model conceptualizes these motivations as dual chambers of the protester's beating heart, with morality and identity both binding and mutually obligating individuals to act in concert. 4 Against this backdrop, this research synthesis 5 moves beyond previous meta-analytic findings (van Zomeren et al., 2008) by testing four (rather than three) unique motivations for collective action (identity, morality, injustice, and efficacy). This nuance enables us to replicate and extend previous conclusions about why people engage in collective action, as well as break new theoretical ground by integrating morality into a more comprehensive and potentially cross-cultural model of collective action. Moreover, the larger and culturally more diverse database of studies allows us to test whether these four motivations extend to advantaged group members acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged and integrates structural constraints (including theoretically relevant cultural constraints) to these four motivations.

Such a research synthesis is both timely and urgent. Scientifically, the psychological literature on collective action has mushroomed over the last decade, 6 resembling the proverbial runaway horse that may be just about to escape us. A new research synthesis can serve to reign in our runaway horse to cover its tracks back to where it came from, to better chart the way forward-especially because this period also witnessed the emergence of moral psychology (e.g., Ellemers et al., 2019;Haidt, 2007). Moreover, the popularity of the topic seems to have increased: The current database is very diverse, about seven times larger than the one from a previous meta-analysis (van Zomeren et al., 2008), and includes studies of collective action among different groups (e.g., not just disadvantaged groups but also advantaged groups acting in solidarity with disadvantaged groups), different contexts (e.g., different types of disadvantage), and different cultures (e.g., with study origins ranging from China and Japan to Indonesia and New Zealand, from Chile and Mexico to the United States and Canada, and across a variety of European countries 7 ). The latter affords a unique opportunity to connect and integrate the psychology of collective action with cultural psychology (e.g., Hofstede, 2010;Schwartz, 2008;Oyserman et al., 2002). 2 We use the terminology of "constraints" because we know less about when motivations for collective action become less powerful. Nonetheless, structural factors can also afford motivations for collective action, which is also what we will test in this quantitative research synthesis. 3 We use umbrella terms such as "morality" and "identity" to specifically refer to moral and social identity motivations for collective action. 4 We borrow this terminology from Oyserman et al. (2002, p. 5), who conceptualized the cultural notion of collectivism in precisely these terms.

The notions of binding and obligating generate a conceptual bridge that allows for connecting the psychology of collective action to moral and cultural psychology (see also Oyserman & Lauffer, 2002, for an application to social movements). This functional view of morality and identity also accommodates that individuals can act together to preserve, rather than challenge, the status quo, for instance when individuals act to protect the system (e.g., Osborne et al., 2019). 5 Many qualitative reviews of this literature are available (e.g., Becker & Tausch, 2015;Kelly & Breinlinger, 1996;Klandermans, 1997Klandermans, , 2004;;Marx & Wood, 1975;McPhail, 1971;van Stekelenburg & Klandermans, 2009;van Zomeren, 2018van Zomeren, , 2019)), but a quantitative research synthesis uniquely enables us to quantify both the size, direction, and interrelationship(s) of the effect(s) of interest. 6 This is also indicated by a variety of special and virtual issues of Furthermore, this research synthesis is societally relevant given the diversity of the many collective action events and movements occurring in the very same decade, including but not limited to the Arab Spring protests and the emergence of movements like Black Lives Matter, MeToo, and Fridays for Future. These recent events and movements raise the question of how generalizable studies from more than 12 years ago may be to inform the practice of contemporary collective action (e.g., the mass protests in the United States after the death of George Floyd in 2020). Indeed, by timing alone the previous meta-analysis could not include studies about the economic crisis in 2008 (e.g., Grasso & Giugni, 2016;Poeschl et al., 2015); the 2011 Arab Spring protests that spread across countries such as Egypt and Tunesia (e.g., Ayanian & Tausch, 2016;Thyen & Gerschewski, 2018); the sudden viral emergence of different online movements (e.g., Kende et al., 2016;Thomas et al., 2015; see also Bennett & Segerberg, 2013;Castells, 2015); the proand anti-immigrant movements in Europe (e.g., Shepherd et al., 2018;Thomas et al., 2019); the ascent of Black Lives Matter in response to events involving police brutality in 2013 (e.g., Leach & Allen, 2017;Klavina & van Zomeren, 2018;Selvanathan et al., 2018); and the emergence of many forms of climate change strikes around 2015 (e.g., Fritsche et al., 2018;Kutlaca et al., 2019). 8 As such, the specific time period since the previous meta-analysis (from 2008 to 2019) is of particular interest, both scientifically and societally, and for both theoretical and applied reasons.

div.head: Goals and Approach
div.p: Our research synthesis enables replication and extension of current knowledge about motivations for collective action. Indeed, our main goals of replication and breaking new theoretical ground fit with various trends in the literature over the last decade. The replication goal fits, for instance, with a trend of increased productivity in the field. As such, there is unprecedented scope for replicating the insights from the previous meta-analysis on a much larger and thus more comprehensive database. 9 The replication goal also fits with another trend of focusing on multiple motivations for collective action. Rather than studies focusing on a single motivation derived from a single perspective (e.g., social identity, as based in social identity theory), researchers now more routinely include multiple motivations for collective action within their studies (e.g., Cakal et al., 2011;Jost et al., 2017). There is thus much more data available on the interrelationships between different motivations for collective action.

Breaking new theoretical ground fits with a recent trend of focusing on morality as a different motivation for collective action, with studies focusing on moral conviction (defined as attitudes on a specific issue that are grounded in core values; Skitka, 2010;van Zomeren et al., 2011van Zomeren et al., , 2012) but also on system justification (reflecting an ideological preference for societal stability; Jost et al., 2017). This research synthesis is therefore the first to metaanalytically evaluate whether there is a sound and solid basis for integrating moral motivations into the heart of the psychology of collective action. If so, this research has at least two important theoretical implications: First, the beating heart of the protester may not only reflect identity but also moral motivations (i.e., it may not only reflect who "we" are but also what "we" stand for; van Zomeren et al., 2018). Second, this research enables a more comprehensive explanation of why members of other groups, such as advantaged group members, can act in solidarity with a disadvantaged group (van Zomeren, 2013).

The goal to break new theoretical ground also fits with a trend of globalization of (the study of) collective action. Indeed, studies use contexts, groups, and samples (i.e., research participants) from all over the globe-which, if only for logistic reasons, was very difficult or even unimaginable not so long ago (e.g., before the advent of the Internet, social media, and research methods to collect international data). In line with critiques that too much psychological knowledge is inferred from a culturally narrow database (e.g., by relying on samples from Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich and Democratic contexts; Henrich et al., 2010; see also Henry, 2008;Sears, 1986), this rich diversity offers an unprecedented opportunity to identify and test theoretically relevant cultural constraints to the four motivations for collective action-a focus not at all common in the psychology of collective action (for exceptions see Fischer et al., 2017;van Zomeren & Louis, 2017). As such, we connect the psychology of collective action with insights from cultural psychology (e.g., Hofstede, 1980;Oyserman et al., 2002;Schwartz, 1992) to answer the question of whether the protester's heart beats the same across the globe.

To this end, we conducted four meta-analyses, each on a different motivation for collective action: Identity, injustice, efficacy, and, for the first time, morality. We expected to replicate previous meta-analytic findings (van Zomeren et al., 2008) that identity, injustice, and efficacy show unique and positive medium-sized effects; and to newly find that morality is a fourth unique and positive motivation. We also meta-analyzed the interrelationships between the four motivations, expecting positive relationships between the three established motivations and, newly, also between morality and the other motivations for collective action-in particular, between morality and identity, which reflect the dual chambers of the protester's beating heart. We further tested previous conclusions that the strongest motivations for collective action are politicized identity (e.g., identification with a movement rather than with the broader disadvantaged group) and emotional injustice (e.g., group-based anger rather than perceptions of unfairness). Moreover, we tested new motivational and structural moderator variables. For example, based on indications from the literature we examined whether moral conviction is as strong a motivation for collective action as politicized identity and emotional injustice. Furthermore, we identified and tested theoretically relevant cultural constraints (such as collectivism and hierarchy values) and contextual constraints (e.g., disadvantaged or advantaged group members as actors) to the four motivations for collective action.

div.head: Toward a Comprehensive and Potentially Cross-Cultural Model of Collective Action
div.p: The history of the sociopsychological literature on collective action is sometimes described as the coming together of different theoretical approaches to motivation (e.g., van Zomeren et al., 2008). Scholars from this literature already made some progress in synthesizing, at most, three motivations for collective action among members of disadvantaged groups (often based in social identity theory; Duncan, 2012;Mummendey et al., 1999;Stürmer & Simon, 2004; see also Wright, 2009) yet made less progress on conceptualizing structural constraints (van Zomeren, 2016c; but see Corcoran et al., 2011). The dual chamber model we propose continues this trend by integrating four motivations for collective action with theoretically relevant structural constraints.

Specifically, previous work integrated three perspectives on motivation: Social identity theory focuses on social identity (e.g., Brown, 2019); relative deprivation theory focuses on perceived and felt injustice as a key motivation for collective action (e.g., Smith et al., 2012Smith et al., , 2018)), and self-efficacy theory on self-efficacy beliefs (e.g., Bandura, 2001). From the 1990s onward, integrative proposals were developed (e.g., Kawakami & Dion, 1995;Simon et al., 1998), inspiring theory and research to combine two or even three of these motivations for collective action (e.g., Mummendey et al., 1999;Stürmer & Simon, 2004;van Zomeren et al., 2008). 10 Over the last decade, this development toward integration culminated in the formulation of several integrative models that wielded social identity as its integrative tool.

For example, the Social Identity model of Collective Action (SIMCA; van Zomeren et al., 2008) was developed based on a meta-analysis of the identity, injustice, and efficacy motivations for collective action. It suggested a key role for disadvantaged group members' identification with that group to not only directly predict collective action (because it makes the group more self-relevant and increases conformity to group norms; van Zomeren et al., 2008) but also indirectly (through the injustice and efficacy motivations). The assumption was thus that collective action requires a relevant social identity on which to act (i.e., a sense of who "we" are) and on which basis to understand and deal with the group's situation (in terms of perceived/felt group-based injustice and efficacy beliefs). In this theoretical universe, collective action would in fact not be possible without a psychologically relevant social identity-a view directly reflected in Wright et al. (1990) often-used definition of collective action: Any action undertaken by an individual as a psychological representative of the group to improve the conditions of his or her group as a whole (emphasis added). Put differently, the protester's beating heart was to be found in his or her social identity. 11 The dual chamber model offers a next theoretical advance, which is based on recent theoretical developments in the collective action literature that we seek to include in our synthesis. For one, moral motivations emerged over the last decade as powerful predictors of collective action, which begs the question of which place it should have in the psychology of collective action. The advent of moral psychology over the last decade (Ellemers et al., 2019;Haidt, 2007Haidt, , 2012) ) offers two reasons for why its place should be a central one. First, morality binds: It often serves as a strong glue that holds social groups together (Ellemers et al., 2019). Indeed, different groups may prioritize different morals that evoke intergroup conflict and an active protection of each group 's morals (e.g., between liberals and conservatives;Haidt, 2012). This process of intergroup value protection (Leal et al., 2020) is often at the core of conflicts between social movements (van Stekelenburg et al., 2009; see also van Stekelenburg & Klandermans, 2009, 2017) and governments or other groups (e.g., Simon & Klandermans, 2001) and thus between those who fight for and against change (e.g., Jost et al., 2017;Osborne et al., 2019). Second, morality obligates: Holding a moral conviction, for example, motivates collective action but also makes people conform to norms about what is the right thing to do or be (e.g., Sabucedo et al., 2018; see also Ellemers, 2017). In the context of collective action at least, morality thus seems to function much like social identity; therefore, the dual chamber model conceptualizes them as the dual chambers of the protester's beating heart. We use this conceptualization as a basis for (a) integrating the other motivations for collective action and (b) identifying theoretically relevant structural constraints to these motivations.

div.head: Integrating Four Motivations for Collective Action
div.p: The dual chamber model integrates four motivations for collective action by painting a portrait of the protester as having a beating heart with morality and identity chambers, on which basis individuals can understand and deal with the group's situation in terms of collective action (that is, through the injustice and efficacy motivations). In essence, the model thus assumes the protester to be an identity manager as much as a value protector (Skitka, 2010;Tetlock, 2002;van Zomeren et al., 2018). 12 This assumption means that although moral and identity motivations both serve to bind and obligate individuals to act in concert, the two rely on different psychological processes and hence should have unique motivational power. Specifically, collective action may then not only be the result of an identity management process to cope with self-evaluative concerns about one's group's low status (i.e., about "who we are") but also include the active defense 13 of what "we" stand for (Skitka, 2010;Tetlock, 2002;van Zomeren et al., 2018). Indeed, research found a strong positive relationship between moral conviction and a relevant social identity (van Zomeren et al., 2011;van Zomeren et al., 2012), which connects who "we" are with what "we" stand for (i.e., identity content; Turner-Zwinkels et al., 2017). A key implication of this line of thought is that the same motivations for collective action may extend to members from other groups, such as advantaged groups, 10 In all these approaches, the causal direction implied (from motivation to action) is strongly assumed. Few studies focus on the consequences of collective action on those motivations (e.g., Tausch & Becker, 2013). 11 This portrayal is also visible in other models (e.g., Abrams & Grant, 2012;Becker & Tausch, 2015;Drury & Reicher, 2009;Thomas et al., 2012;van Zomeren et al., 2012), but none of these models include and integrate morality as a fourth unique motivation for collective action, and identify and integrate structural constraints to these motivations. 12 van Zomeren et al. ( 2018) reviewed research on politicized identity and different moral motivations for collective action, whereas Osborne et al. (2019) combined social identity and system justification motivations in their research (see also De Cristofaro et al., 2021). The dual chamber model, as outlined and tested in this article, offers a broader integrative model that reflects all these developments in the literature. 13 Although this specific literature has focused most on value protection rather than promotion, value promotion processes are also important.

acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged (Curtin et al., 2016;Reimer et al., 2017;Saab et al., 2015;Subaši c et al., 2011;Thomas et al., 2020;van Zomeren, 2013), precisely because they may also be defending or promoting core values.foot_1 Below, we outline how the dual chamber model integrates four perspectives on collective action.

The Social Identity Perspective. Social identity theory (Tajfel, 1978;Tajfel & Turner, 1979) conceptualizes collective action as an identity management strategy (see also Ellemers, 1993;Mummendey et al., 1999) and hence a protester as an "identity manager." SIT assumes that people generally strive for positive social identities, and hence identities that confer low group status, stigma, discrimination, or other types of collective disadvantaged should require an identity management response to maintain a positive self-evaluation. Only under specific perceived sociostructural conditions (that is, when people perceive hope and scope for social change, and when they perceive boundaries between the low-and the high-status group as impermeable), SIT predicts that individuals become motivated to engage in collective action to turn their negative identity into a more positive one (e.g., Becker, 2012;Bettencourt et al., 2001;Scheepers et al., 2006;Turner & Brown, 1978). Individuals' identification with their disadvantaged group should therefore motivate collective action (Ellemers, 1993;Kelly & Breinlinger, 1996;Mummendey et al., 1999;Tajfel, 1978). In line with surveys and experiments demonstrating such a positive relationship (e.g., Simon et al., 1998), van Zomeren et al. (2008) meta-analytically obtained a positive, medium-sized effect for this relationship.

Furthermore, in line with studies among social movement members (e.g., Stürmer & Simon, 2004), van Zomeren et al. (2008) found that politicized identification (i.e., identification with a social movement or activist group) motivated collective action more strongly than nonpoliticized identification. This finding emerged because identification with a group that has clearer goals and stricter norms about acting for the group (as in the case of movements or activist groups) increases a stronger "inner obligation" to act for the group (Blackwood & Louis, 2012;Stürmer & Simon, 2004). As such, this perspective emphasizes the importance of individuals' social identity in binding and mutually obligating individuals to act in concert, and in particular their politicized identity (Alberici & Milesi, 2016;Blackwood & Louis, 2012;Klandermans, 2014;Simon & Klandermans, 2001). The protester's beating heart, then, indeed may be his or her social identity-particularly when this identity is politicized. The current research synthesis seeks to replicate these findings.

Nevertheless, this line of thought cannot explain why members of other groups, such as advantaged groups, would act in solidarity with the disadvantaged (e.g., men acting for gender equality). SIT's analysis implies that members of high-status groups would not experience a need to manage a negative identity and hence would not need to manage it through collective action (Ellemers, 1993;Tajfel, 1978). If anything, one might expect high-status group members to defend their high status-the very opposite of acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged (Leach et al., 2002;van Zomeren, 2013). Nevertheless, the dual chamber model suggests that collective action is not the monopoly of disadvantaged group members (e.g., van Zomeren, 2013)-individuals from other groups, such as advantaged groups, can act in solidarity with the disadvantaged (e.g., Curtin et al., 2016;Reimer et al., 2017;Saab et al., 2015;Subaši c et al., 2011). For this reason, the current research synthesis evaluates whether the same motivations for collective action extend to advantaged group members.

The Morality Perspective. The emergence of moral psychology (e.g., Ellemers, 2018;Haidt, 2007Haidt, , 2012;;Skitka, 2010) inspired scientific interest in moral motivations for collective action (e.g., Jost et al., 2017;Milesi & Alberici, 2018;Sabucedo et al., 2018;van Stekelenburg et al., 2009;van Stekelenburg & Klandermans, 2009), which includes motivations based in values, moral principles or beliefs, or ideology. In particular, collective action research has recently emphasized the concepts of moral conviction and system justification. Based on value protection models (e.g., Tetlock, 2002); if people hold moral convictions on an issue (e.g., education as a universal human right) and these convictions are threatened (e.g., when a government proposes to implement tuition fees), then the perceived violation of these moral beliefs and principles, and the resulting emotional experience (e.g., anger), motivate them to engage in action to defend core values from attack through collective action (e.g., Kutlaca et al., 2019;Leal et al., 2019;Mazzoni et al., 2015;Shuman et al., 2019;Skitka, 2010;van Zomeren, 2013van Zomeren, , 2011;;van Zomeren et al., 2012). This form of morality reflects a deontological view that is conceptually indicative of a more general value protection process that the dual chamber model puts at the heart of the psychology of collective action. The current research synthesis tests this idea.

Moreover, collective action researchers recently focused on system justification,foot_2 an ideological motive to justify and uphold the system in which one is embedded (e.g., Jost et al., 2004). In this view, individuals have individual motives (e.g., self-interest) and group motives (e.g., group esteem), but also system motives that may explain, for example, why people from disadvantaged groups do not protest (but see Owuamalam et al., 2018 for a critique). For example, system justification dampens individuals' willingness to engage in collective action for progressive causes as it makes them less angry and decreases their identification with their group (Jost et al., 2017). Yet system justification can also motivate collective action to protect the system (Osborne et al., 2019). For this reason, this research synthesis also includes system justification as a type of moral motivation for collective action.

The Injustice Perspective. The dual chamber model conceptualizes the injustice and efficacy motivations as unique motivations for collective action, as these help individuals to understand and deal with the group's situation (van Zomeren et al., 2012). Given that the protester's sense of who "we" are and what "we" stand for affects such understandings, the model views the injustice and efficacy motivations as downstream motivational consequences of the protester's heart. With respect to injustice, relative deprivation theory conceptualizes the protester as a "passionate responder" to perceived injustices (Smith et al., 2012;van Zomeren et al., 2012). This motivation is based on the perception and feeling of relative deprivation-to perceive or feel as being worse off compared with others (e.g., to feel deprived, disadvantaged, and/or discriminated against; Abrams & Grant, 2012). The theory further specifies how social comparisons (Crosby, 1976;Grant et al., 2017;Runciman, 1966;Smith & Ortiz, 2002;Stouffer et al., 1949) with those who are unfairly better-off will yield the perception of relative deprivation. Importantly, experiencing relative deprivation as group-based, for example, because one compares the situation of one's group with another group that is unfairly better-off, is more strongly related to collective action than experiencing it as individual-based (Dubé-Simard & Guimond, 1986;Runciman, 1966). 16 In line with the findings of primary studies, Van Zomeren et al.'s (2008) meta-analysis found a unique, positive, medium-sized relationship between perceived injustice and collective action. The current research synthesis seeks to replicate this finding.

Furthermore, the emotional experience of group-based relative deprivation is more strongly related to collective action than its perception (Smith et al., 2012). This association is because the emotional experience of injustice (e.g., anger) strengthens the motivation to act (Frijda, 1986;Lazarus, 1991; see also Guimond & Dubé-Simard, 1983;van Zomeren et al., 2004), and the perception of injustice is central to emotions like anger (Carver & Harmon-Jones, 2009;Lazarus, 1991;Scherer et al., 2001). Consistent with the findings of primary studies (e.g., Li et al., 2019;Shi et al., 2015;Wlodarczyk et al., 2017), van Zomeren et al. (2008) found in their meta-analysis that felt injustice produced higher effect sizes than perceived injustice. The current research synthesis seeks to replicate this finding.

The Efficacy Perspective. The notion of efficacy has been guided by two different perspectives that each help individuals understand their group's situation in a different way. The first perspective conceptualizes efficacy as a proxy for the perceived effectiveness of collective action, which derives from approaches such as the theory of planned behavior (Ajzen, 1991) and psychological forms of resource mobilization theory (e.g., Klandermans, 1984;Olson, 1968;Simon et al., 1998). The portrait of the protester is a rather "cold calculator" of the costs and benefits of joining such action. This individualistic and instrumental (i.e., outcome-oriented) portrait is strikingly different from the other portrayals of the protester (i.e., as an identity manager, value protector, and passionate responder to group-based injustice), which may be why scholars tended to consider this view on efficacy as reflecting a rather different and individualistic motivation for collective action (e.g., Hornsey et al., 2006;Klandermans, 1984;Opp, 2009;van Zomeren et al., 2012). 17 A second perspective on efficacy is more closely aligned with these portrayals, as it identifies self-efficacy beliefs as a core manifestation of human agency (based on the human faculty of forethought; Bandura, 1997). Self-efficacy beliefs indicate that one can achieve relevant goals through personal effort, and because such goals can be group goals, the notion of self-efficacy applies to groups and collective action as well (Bandura, 1997;2001;Mummendey et al., 1999). Indeed, the notion of group efficacy beliefs is conceptualized as the belief that the group can achieve group goals through joint effort (Mummendey et al., 1999;Ufkes et al., 2015Ufkes et al., , 2016;;van Zomeren et al., 2004van Zomeren et al., , 2012)); which motivates collective action. Group efficacy beliefs can also be specified to include individuals' own contribution to these group efforts to achieve group goals (i.e., participative efficacy beliefs), which may increase its motivational power (Bamberg et al., 2015;van Zomeren et al., 2013). The portrait of the protester in this perspective is not a "cold calculator" but an "agentic team player." As such, the dual chamber model assumes that both types of efficacy motivate collective action for different reasons.

Indeed, Van Zomeren et al.'s (2008) previous meta-analysis did not make this distinction and found, in line with the findings from surveys and experiments, a positive and medium-sized effect of efficacy on collective action. Because it is unclear to what extent this estimate conflates self-efficacy with perceived effectiveness, the current research synthesis seeks to replicate this finding while newly testing which type of efficacy may yield stronger effect sizes.

New Predictions From an Integrative Perspective. The dual chamber model generates at least three new sets of predictions regarding motivations for collective action. First, it predicts a strong and positive relationship between morality and identity. This relationship is likely because moral convictions can powerfully define the content of people's social identity, such as when moralizing abortion fits with one's identity as a feminist, or when one's student identity fits with the belief that education should be free to all (Kutlaca et al., 2016;Turner-Zwinkels et al., 2017). Yet stronger identification with a group can also strengthen specific moral convictions (Leal et al., 2020), which may be why such convictions are particularly strongly related to politicized group identities (as these often have a clear and normative content; van Zomeren, 2013). This idea suggests that moral convictions should therefore not just be positively related but may also reflect as strong a motivation for collective action as politicized identity. 18 Second, we hypothesize a positive relationship between moral conviction and perceived/felt injustice because the underlying value protection process is highly emotive and hence is likely to foster strong perceptions of injustice and strong emotions such as anger (e.g., van Zomeren, Kutlaca, et al., 2018). As for the relationship between morality and efficacy, van Zomeren et al. (2011van Zomeren et al. ( , 2012) ) reported a mixture of positive and null correlations but 16 In fact, the perception and experience of individual-based relative deprivation has negative effects on individuals' mental and physical health (e.g., Mishra & Carleton, 2015). 17 This approach dates back to Olson (1968), of which some have suggested it might actually paint a better portrait of the non-protester than of the protester (e.g., van Zomeren, 2016b). This is because such an approach assumes that perceived effectiveness holds a multiplicative relationship with "value," thus implying that perceived effectiveness may be particularly relevant for individuals who do not value the group and are likely to look for opportunities to free-ride. 18 A relatively new concept in the literature is opinion-based group identity (e.g., McGarty et al., 2009;Thomas et al., 2009Thomas et al., , 2012))-the idea that individuals can identify with groups grounded in a shared opinion. We note clear similarities here with the notions of politicized identity, as this often refers to social movements, which are often groups with a very clear opinion; and moral conviction, which reflects a clear opinion as well. We will therefore explore the motivational power of opinion-based group identification in the current research synthesis.

concluded that a positive relationship can be expected because holding a moral conviction may imply an almost self-evident belief that achieving one's moral goals is possible-or in fact has to be possible, particularly when others violate one's convictions.

We thus also hypothesize a positive relationship between moral conviction and efficacy. Third, such predictions should be the opposite for system justification (in the context of collective action aiming for progressive change). Indeed, system justification should generally demotivate such collective action as it indicates that people ideologically prioritize maintaining the status quo (e.g., Jost et al., 2017). Because system justification also relates to the motivated legitimization of existing disadvantages in society and disidentification with the disadvantaged, we expect it to be negatively related to the identity, injustice, and efficacy motivations for collective action.

div.head: Integrating Structural Constraints to Motivations for Collective Action
div.p: The dual chamber model integrates theoretically relevant structural constraints to the four motivations for collective action. This consideration is important because we do not know whether the dual chamber model is potentially cross-culturally and because neither current theory nor research offers clear pointers toward potential other contextual constraints (but see Corcoran et al., 2011;van Zomeren & Louis, 2017). Our research synthesis thus both generates and tests new predictions about structural constraints.

Contextual Constraints. There are conceptual and empirical reasons for why we currently know little about structural constraints to motivations for collective action. Conceptually, only social identity theory has something to say about (perceived) structural constraints. This theory predicts that collective action will not be a viable option in the absence of perceived hope and scope for social change (Cohen-Chen & Van Zomeren, 2018;van Zomeren et al., 2019) and when boundaries between the groups are perceived as permeable (which invites low-status group members to leave their group; Ellemers, 1993;Tajfel, 1978;Wright et al., 1990). Unfortunately, there is hardly any research on these structural conditions and collective action, and in the few available cases (e.g., Mummendey et al., 1999;van Zomeren et al., 2016) results were not quite in line with predictions. 19Furthermore, empirically, there may also be little variance in structural conditions across collective action studies and hence any constraints will be difficult to detect (e.g., McAdam & Boudet, 2012;van Zomeren, 2016b). Researchers typically select contexts in which collective action is already likely or ongoing and hence there already is hope and scope for social change (van Zomeren, 2016b). Put differently, researchers seem to be interested in why people engage in collective action when the opportunity is there, rather than that they are interested in how this opportunity arises (McAdam & Boudet, 2012). The lack of interest in this area raises an important boundary to the interpretation of the effect sizes synthesized from these studies-namely, that most findings of why people engage in collective action are embedded in conditions already favorable to collective action. 20Against this backdrop, we identified and tested theoretically relevant contextual constraints. First, we examined whether the four motivations extend to members of other groups, such as advantaged groups, who act in solidarity with the disadvantaged (e.g., Curtin et al., 2016;Reimer et al., 2017;Saab et al., 2015;Subaši c et al., 2011;Thomas et al., 2020;van Zomeren, 2013). Whereas social identity theory, in its basic logic, views low group status as a boundary condition (and high group status as a clear structural constraint), the dual chamber model does not as it integrates moral motivations that foster acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged, which may lead them to identify with the disadvantaged (or with opinion-based groups devoted to fighting for the disadvantaged; Thomas et al., 2020). The current research synthesis uniquely included studies of collective action among advantaged group members, which affords the opportunity to test whether the four motivations are constrained by, or extend to, the advantaged.

Second, we examined type of disadvantage, characterized as ranging from incidental to structural disadvantage. Whereas structural disadvantage is often indicated by discrimination based on negative stereotypes (e.g., discrimination based on gender, race, ethnicity, or sexuality) with severely negative implications for social identity, incidental disadvantage reflects more of a single problem that the group needs to solve without clear cues to negative social identity (e.g., students wanting to stop the increase of tuition fees). van Zomeren et al. (2008) found that the injustice and efficacy mean effect sizes were weaker for collective action against structural than against incidental disadvantages, while there was no difference for the identity mean effect size. This finding implies that structural disadvantage may act as a contextual constraint on these motivations, and thus the current research synthesis seeks to replicate these findings.

Cultural Constraints. Identifying and testing theoretically relevant cultural constraints is important for three reasons. First, this research fits with a recent trend in the collective action literature to consider cross-cultural differences (e.g., Fischer et al., 2017;van Zomeren & Louis, 2017) enabled by the increased cultural diversity of research samples, and questions about the crosscultural validity of models of collective action. Second, identifying cultural constraints stimulates theoretical integration. Specifically, the dual chamber model's assumption that the moral and identity motivations serve similar bind-and-obligate functions offers a conceptual zone of convergence between the protester's beating heart and the broader cultural values in which he or she is embedded (e.g., in terms of collectivism and hierarchy values). Indeed, as cultural beings, individuals seek to understand and deal with (group) situations they face based on broader shared understandings (Oyserman et al., 2002; see also Oyserman & Lauffer, 2002). Such shared norms about what is valued within a culture may therefore affect the protester's beating heart, both in terms of who "we" are and what "we" stand for.

Third, the emergence of cultural psychology since the 1980s (e.g., Bond, 1988;Kagitcibasi & Berry, 1989) increased concerns in psychology about the potential relativity of Western findings and ideas, and hence about the need for theories that identify key cross-cultural differences (Smith et al., 2013). For example, Henrich and colleagues (2010) argued against the dominant use of Western samples for research, as it leads to Western theories suggesting a healthy caution in generalizing findings from such research to non-Western samples (van Zomeren, 2016c;van Zomeren & Louis, 2017). Henrich et al. (2010) indeed found considerable cross-cultural differences in core psychological domains relevant to collective action, including fairness, moral reasoning, self-concepts, and related motivations. This finding may warrant caution in applying a too Western portrait of the protester to non-Western cultural settings and samples. 21 At the same time, cultural psychology offers broad and influential models of cultural dimensions and values that reflect meaningful cross-cultural variance (e.g., Hofstede, 1980;2001;Markus & Kitayama, 2010;Oyserman et al., 2002;Schwartz, 1992), despite disagreements about their precise number, meaning, and measurement (e.g., Vignoles et al., 2016). We identified theoretically relevant cultural dimensions and values based on two considerations. First, if morality and identity serve to bind and obligate individuals, then theoretically relevant cultural dimensions and values should reflect cultural variance related to such motivations (e.g., collectivism). Second, theoretically relevant cultural dimensions and values needed to be available as country-level data (e.g., scores on collectivism) so that we could use them in our research synthesis. We therefore chose to use the cultural dimensions and values derived from Hofstede (2001) and Schwartz (2008) as analytical tools, which reflect cross-cultural variance in what is valued within cultures, and offer theoretically relevant (e.g., collectivism, hierarchy, egalitarianism) cultural dimensions and values. 22 We generated hypotheses only for theoretically relevant dimensions and values while taking an explorative approach to others. 23 Specifically, from the Hofstede cultural dimensions we identified collectivism (the degree to which individuals are integrated into groups) as a potential cultural constraint, and from the Schwartz cultural values, we identified hierarchy values (the degree to which people are socialized to take hierarchical distribution of roles for granted) and egalitarian values (the degree to which people recognize one another as moral equals, and are socialized to internalize a commitment to cooperate and to feel concerned for everyone's welfare) as potential cultural constraints to the protester's beating heart.

We then generated testable hypotheses. First, collectivism speaks directly to the protester's beating heart at the cultural level-that is, collectivism binds and mutually obligates individuals into groups (Oyserman et al., 2002;p. 5) and hence should reflect meaningful cross-cultural variance. Collectivism may reflect, on average, a stronger psychological self-relevance of the group and its goals to the individual, and hence stronger collectivism may afford the identity and morality motivations for collective action. At the same time, however, collectivism may constrain these motivations because individuals also feel bound to the broader system in which one's group is embedded (van Zomeren et al., 2016). Our research synthesis will test both possibilities.

Second, Schwartz's hierarchy and egalitarian values are theoretically relevant because cultures that fall more on the hierarchy side of the egalitarian-hierarchy continuum are socialized to take hierarchical distribution of roles for granted (Schwartz, 2008), which implies a focus on acceptance and justification of power differences. Hierarchy may even be valued to such an extent that justifying the system is not just a cultural norm but part of a conservative ideology (Jost et al., 2017). Against this backdrop, cultural hierarchy values may constrain the morality and identity motivations for collective action. Conversely, cultures that value egalitarianism imply a focus on recognizing one another as moral equals and being concerned with everyone's welfare (Schwartz, 2004). This concept implies a focus on social justice, equality, and responsibility, all of which may make the protester's heart grow fonder. As such, we hypothesize that hierarchy values act as a cultural constraint and egalitarian values as a cultural affordance. 24

div.head: Research Questions and Predictions
div.p: Our quantitative research synthesis seeks to answer several sets of specific research questions. Key sets of questions are: Do identity, injustice, and efficacy yield positive, medium-sized effects? Does morality yield a positive, medium-sized effect? Furthermore, do all four motivations have unique effects on collective action (i.e., when controlling for the others)? If these questions are answered affirmatively, the psychology of collective action should be based on four, rather than three, motivations for collective action.

Second, we ask whether all four motivations for collective action are positively interrelated. We thus seek to replicate previous meta-analytic findings that identity, injustice, and efficacy are positively related, and newly expect to find that morality relates positively to all three other motivations (and in particular to identity). If confirmed, this finding would support a need for theoretical integration as proposed in the dual chamber model.

Third, we turn to questions about specific moderators on the side of motivation. Does politicized identification yield stronger 21 "Cross-cultural" does not imply "universal," as the latter can be understood as having evolutionary or other nondescriptive connotations. We remain agnostic about such connotations here and use "cross-cultural" as a descriptive term.

22 Individualism and collectivism are not necessarily related (Oyserman et al., 2002;Reis et al., 2013). Because we relied here on Hofstede's and Schwartz's indicators and country-level data, our collectivism indicator assumes a negative relationship between individualism and collectivism. 23 We assume that variance in country-level dimensions (e.g., on collectivism) reflects variance in cultural norms that percolate into the samples of studies on collective action, and hence can be used to meaningfully test predictions about potential cultural constraints (e.g., does identity have a weaker relationship with collective action in more collectivist countries?). To this end, we also included in our database, where available, the reported means and standard deviations for any motivation for collective action. This information allows interpretation of cultural differences in terms of how self-relevant the different motivations are (i.e., higher or lower means) or in terms of constraints to their motivational power (i.e., stronger or weaker effects). 24 We expected power distance (the degree to which power differences between groups are accepted) to act as a cultural constraint for the same reason as for hierarchy values. Furthermore, we reasoned that harmony values would act as cultural constraints because valuing harmony (Fischer et al., 2017;Taras et al., 2010) implies avoiding conflictual identity management strategies such as collective action (van Zomeren et al., 2016).

effects than nonpoliticized identification? Does the emotional experience of injustice yield stronger effects than perceived injustice? Moving beyond previous work, does moral conviction yield similarly strong effects as politicized identity? And do group and participative efficacy beliefs (reflecting the agentic team player) yield similarly strong effects as perceived effectiveness (reflecting the cold calculator of costs and benefits)? Answering these questions will identify the strongest motivations for collective action. Fourth, on the side of structural constraints, we test for moderating effects of the cultural and other contextual factors we identified as relevant to the protester's beating heart. For cultural factors, we test whether collectivism and hierarchy values constrain the identity and moral motivations for collective action (whereas egalitarian values should afford them). For contextual factors, we test whether the four motivations are constrained by, or can be extended to, members of other groups, such as advantaged groups, acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged, and by or to structural and incidental types of disadvantage. 25 Answering these questions will tell us whether the protester's heart beats the same across the globe and also extends to others who seek to act in solidarity with the disadvantaged.

Fifth and finally, we use meta-analytic structural equation modeling to directly evaluate the added value of integrating morality into the psychology of collective action, compared with the integrative model derived from the previous meta-analysis (that did not include morality; van Zomeren et al., 2008).

div.head: Method
div.p: We used a meta-analytic approach because a meta-analysis can assess the strength of the relationship between a predictor and a criterion variable across different measures, methods, groups, contexts, and cultures; answer the question of how different predictors are related to one another; test for moderator variables pertaining to types of motivation as well as types of structural constraints; and test different models through meta-analytic structural equation modeling.

div.head: Criteria for Inclusion and Operational Definitions
div.p: Our main criteria for inclusion were that studies had to report primary data quantifying the association between one or more motivations and collective action, embedded within a group context that allowed for inferences about its presumed goal (see the PRISMA document, particularly Table 1 in online supplemental materials, for detailed information regarding article exclusion). 26Such criteria already exclude, for example, studies using secondary data, qualitative studies of collective action, and studies that relied on objective rather than subjective measures of identity, morality, injustice, and/or efficacy. We also included studies only when we had sufficient statistical information available (either from the article or from contacting the authors) to calculate the relevant effect size. Furthermore, studies had to include variables that conformed to our operational definitions, which we outline below. Across the board, these criteria for inclusion brought down our initial potential pool of articles from 8,567 to 231. Unsurprisingly, most articles included in our database were part of the specific psychological collective action literature this research seeks to synthesize.

div.head: Collective Action
div.p: Operationally, most studies of collective action operationalized the concept through specific means of social protest, such as when participants are asked about their participation in a movement, or their willingness to sign a petition or participate in a demonstration. In line with van Zomeren et al. (2008), we included behavioral measures, but also proxies of such behavior (e.g., attitudinal support or intentions). Typical examples of such measures are: "signing a petition to improve the current situation of Blacks in South Africa" (e.g., Cakal et al., 2011;p. 611), and "participating in a demonstration" (e.g., Cohen-Chen & Van Zomeren, 2018;p. 52).

Other measures of collective action had to fit with the conceptual definition we used (van Zomeren, 2013); which acknowledged and extended Wright et al.'s (1990) definition to include disadvantaged and other group members' actions as a representative of a group, and where the action was directed at improving the conditions of the disadvantaged group. This definition emphasizes that individuals can act on behalf of their group and that such actions psychologically constitute collective action. It follows that such action needed to be embedded in a group context, in which we could at least make a reasonable assumption that the action on behalf of the group was aimed at improving the conditions of a group as a whole. Thus, we excluded studies when there was no clear collective disadvantage and hence no context in which action could be aimed at improving the conditions of the group, or when studies measured action in individual or interpersonal contexts (e.g., the willingness to use violence to further one's own goals; Doosje et al., 2012; bringing up feminist issues in a personal conversation; Redford et al., 2018).

Furthermore, and in line with developments in the literature (van Zomeren, 2013), we included studies that focused on solidarity-based action of members from other groups, such as advantaged groups acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged group. As such, we were open to the collective actions of different actors but kept the presumed goal (i.e., improving the conditions of the disadvantaged group) and the context of collective action (i.e., a group context) constant.

div.head: Identity
div.p: Conceptually, we included studies that measured social identity motivations for collective action. Operationally, most studies employed measures of group identification, which often include items such as "I identify with [group X]" (e.g., Turner-Zwinkels et al., 2016;p. 150). Studies included used measures of politicized identity (i.e., identification with a social movement, or as an activist), measures of nonpoliticized identity (i.e., identification with context of collective disadvantage within which collective action acquires its psychological meaning (typically a group context within which individuals may act to improve the position of the relevant disadvantaged group). In most cases we could reasonably assume a subjectively perceived collective disadvantage because of empirical indications (e.g., measures of such disadvantage, or unfairness or anger pointing at the subjective perception of such disadvantage), whereas in other cases we could reasonably assume such a perception given the specific context (e.g., for Black Lives Matter supporters, we felt we could safely assume that they would perceive Blacks to be collectively disadvantaged). the disadvantaged group; e.g., van Breen et al., 2017;p. 3;van Zomeren et al., 2012;p. 58), as well as measures of opinion-based group identity (i.e., identification with groups characterized by a shared opinion such as being against poverty; e.g., Thomas & McGarty, 2009, p. 124).

div.head: Morality
div.p: Conceptually, we included studies that measured the moral motivations of collective action. Operationally, we included measures of moral conviction, perceived violation of moral beliefs or principles, and system justification. Moral convictions were typically measured with items such as "My opinion on climate change is part of my core moral norms and values" (van Zomeren et al., 2019;p. 58), whereas perceived violation of moral principles would be measured with items such as "The decision to cut the budget for higher education is against universal moral values" (Kutlaca et al., 2016). System justification was typically measured with items such as "Most policies . . . serve the greater good" (Cichocka et al., 2017;p. 7).

div.head: Injustice
div.p: Conceptually, we included studies that measured injustice motivations for collective action. The operational definition of injustice included measures of perceptions and/or feelings of unfairness as well as relative deprivation. Typical examples of measures of injustice are: "People like me are treated unfairly" (e.g., Becker, 2012;p. 652), "I think the introduction of tuition fees is unfair" (e.g., Tausch et al., 2011;p. 133), and "I feel angry/frustrated because of the way we are treated" (e.g., Grant et al., 2017;p. 459;Iyer & Ryan, 2009;p. 800).

div.head: Efficacy
div.p: Conceptually, we included studies that measured efficacy motivations for collective action. Operationally, we included measures of group and participative efficacy, and measures of perceived effectiveness and instrumentality. Typical examples of measures of group and participative efficacy beliefs are: "To what extent do you think that [group] will be able to achieve their goals together?" (e.g., Saeri et al., 2015;p. 5), "I think that together we can change [the group-related problem]" (e.g., Stewart & Tran, 2018;p. 304), and "As an individual, I think I can meaningfully contribute to achieving [the group-related problem] through unified effort" (e.g., Mazzoni et al., 2015;p. 319;van Zomeren et al., 2013;p. 621).

div.head: Literature Search
div.p: We conducted a broad/top-down literature search via multiple databases (e.g., the PsycINFO, and Web of Science databases, from June 2007 to September 2018), using combinations of keywords, with examples being collective action, protest, injustice, unfairness, deprivation, agency, efficacy, effectiveness, identity, identification, morality, system justification, and violated principles (see the OSF repository for all details, code book, and PRISMA flowchart for exclusion examples as well as a detailed explanation of the articles, samples, and effect sizes that were included/excluded; full data for the full 8,567 articles is available on OSF). In addition, in a narrow/bottom-up fashion, we systematically searched the reference sections of review articles to identify potentially yet uncovered relevant studies and contacted researchers known to have conducted published or unpublished studies on the topic. Furthermore, we sent requests for relevant studies and unpublished data via the mailing lists of different European (EASP) and American (SPSSI, ISPP) professional organizations. Together, this combined top-down/broad and bottom-up/ narrow search approach resulted in 2.7% of the pool of potentially relevant articles to be included.

We stopped adding new entries to the database in April 2019. A total of 231 articles fulfilled the above-mentioned criteria with 403 samples (264 for identity, 81 for morality, 259 samples for injustice, and 216 for efficacy). From the samples, we extracted in total 1,235 effect sizes (390 for identity, 121 for morality, 409 for injustice, and 315 for efficacy). In terms of participant numbers, the total sample size for identity was N = 77,315; for morality was N = 24,708; for injustice was N = 82,346; and for efficacy was N = 56,784. In addition, a considerable subset of the samples in the database (n = 101) included effect size estimates from multiple predictors (n = 65 had identity, injustice, and efficacy; n = 36 had all four motivations). In total, there are k = 101 correlations for identity-injustice, k = 36 for identity-morality, k = 101 for identity-efficacy, k = 36 for injusticemorality, k = 101 for injustice-efficacy and k = 36 for morality- efficacy). The OSF repository lists all included samples, effect sizes extracted, and sample sizes on which they are based, together with the coding information for each coded variable (doi.org/10.17605/ OSF.IO/V7BWK). We also provide all the R-code and output there.

div.head: Coding of Moderators
div.p: Based in part on van Zomeren et al. ( 2008), we developed a coding book (see OSF repository). We coded for nonsubstantive moderator variables, such as mean age, gender composition, type of collective action, and type of method. We also coded and differentiated between motivational and structural moderators, which refer to moderators about motivation as identified in the previous meta-analysis (e.g., politicized vs. nonpoliticized identification, emotional vs. perceived injustice), moderators about motivation as derived from more recent theory and research (moral conviction vs. system justification, group and participative efficacy vs. perceived effectiveness), and structural constraints, including cultural moderators (e.g., collectivism, hierarchy values) and other contextual moderators (type of group, type of disadvantage).

Two coders independently read the articles and rated characteristics and moderator variables (some categorical, some at interval level). For the categorical moderator variables, the overall intercoder agreement was good (Cohen's j = .96). The largest discrepancies were still in an acceptable range (i.e., type efficacy coding, Cohen's j = .84; for full information, see header 2 in the OSF repository HTML file). Disagreements were solved through discussion.

div.head: Type of Identity
div.p: We coded for politicized and nonpoliticized group identities. Politicized groups often corresponded to social movements or activist groups, whereas nonpoliticized groups often referred to the broader disadvantaged group (e.g., van Breen et al., 2017). In line with developments in the last decade, we also coded for opinionbased group identities (e.g., Thomas & McGarty, 2009). 27

div.head: Type of Morality
div.p: We coded for moral conviction (i.e., beliefs on an issue that reflect perceived absolute right/wrongs), violated beliefs or principles (see Sabucedo et al., 2018), and for system justification (when referred to as such; Jost et al., 2019).

div.head: Type of Injustice
div.p: We coded for emotional and perceived injustice (see Livingstone et al., 2009, for a differentiation). Typical measures of emotional measures are feelings of group-based anger or affective relative deprivation. Typical examples of perceptual measures are perceptions/appraisals of unfairness, illegitimacy, injustice, and cognitive relative deprivation.

div.head: Type of Efficacy
div.p: We coded for type of efficacy by assessing whether group and participative efficacy beliefs (e.g., van Zomeren et al., 2013) or perceived effectiveness (or instrumentality) were used (e.g., Hornsey et al., 2006).

div.head: Type of Group
div.p: We coded for whether the sample in question was a disadvantaged group (directly affected by the circumstances of the collective action context, or at least perceived as such), or an advantaged group that acted in solidarity with the disadvantaged group (see e.g., Iyer & Ryan, 2009; for a differentiation). In a few cases, we also coded for so-called third groups, who are not disadvantaged themselves, as advantaged groups. We further coded how the group could be characterized within Deaux et al. (1995) typology (i.e., based in vocation, stigma, political affiliation, or nationality/ ethnicity), or whether the group was solidarity-based.

div.head: Type of Disadvantage
div.p: We coded for structural or incidental disadvantage through a dichotomous and continuous rating (see van Zomeren et al., 2008). Structural disadvantage was related to discrimination based on ethnicity, gender, sexuality, nationality. Incidental disadvantage was related to an external problem that, once solved, leaves the group to be no longer disadvantaged (e.g., students facing tuition cuts).

div.head: Type of Culture
div.p: We coded cultural dimensions and values in two ways. First, we used a somewhat crude coding indicating whether the sample's country background was Western or non-Western (see the online supplemental materials for more details and a table of all countries). Second, we matched the country-level coding of the sample with country-level data about the Hofstede (2010) dimensions and Schwartz's (2008) values. We standardized these scales to be able to compare them with each other.

div.head: Nonsubstantive and Explorative Moderators
div.p: Because studies may differ on nontheoretical dimensions as well, we coded for several variables. For one, we recorded the mean age of the sample, when reported. When data were missing, we made an informed guess (e.g., students are likely to be around 20). We also recorded the gender composition of the sample, when reported; categories were female, male, or mixed. Furthermore, we coded whether a nonbehavioral measure of collective action was used (intentions to engage in or attitudinal support for collective action) or a behavioral measure (behavior or self-reported past behavior); whether the research used survey or experimental methods; and whether the effect in question could be interpreted causally (e.g., experimental manipulation, or longitudinal design with time lag), or not. Exploratively, we also coded for whether the type of collective action was violent or not, and whether it was an online or offline form of action. 28

div.head: Statistical Approach
div.p: We used the correlation coefficient r as our effect size measure because a large proportion of research in the sample was correlational. When we speak of "effects," we thus refer empirically to correlations, although conceptually we assume that "motivations" predict "collective action." When needed, we converted other effect sizes reported to r using the formulas provided by Rosenthal (1979). We used Cohen's (1992) interpretation of effect sizes of .10 as small, .30 as medium, and .50 as large. We used a randomeffects model analysis because of the large diversity in contexts, groups, and cultures (Lipsey & Wilson, 2001;Rosenthal, 1979). We computed weighted averages of the effect sizes based on Fisher's (1921) to z-transformed correlations (Zr; Viechtbauer, 2010;p. 8).

Each independent sample was treated as an independent data point. When multiple effect sizes could be computed for one sample, we aggregated these effect sizes to one average r to avoid statistical interdependence. Yet when multiple effect sizes were available that corresponded to different levels of moderator variables (e.g., type of identity, type of injustice), we separated these effects out for those particular analyses. As such, the total number of effect sizes is larger than the number of effect sizes for independent samples. This method ensures that each statistical test was conducted on statistically independent data. 29 We used the R packages metafor (Viechtbauer, 2010(Viechtbauer, , 2017) and metaSEM (Cheung, 2014(Cheung, , 2015;;Jak & Cheung, 2019) for moderation tests and meta-analytic structural equation modeling. All analyses were run in R (R Core Team, 2019) and RStudio (RStudio Team, 2019). Variation in effect sizes was examined with the Q E -statistic (i.e., an index of residual heterogeneity presented on OSF) as well as the s 2 statistic (i.e., an absolute value of residual heterogeneity presented in the accompanying tables; Borenstein et al., 2017). Effects of potential moderator variables were examined by computing analyses of variance providing estimates of between-group variance (Q M ). Each individual effect was estimated with regression analyses. For categorical moderator variables, we used dummy coding while continuous variables were centered or standardized. Regression analysis thereby provided us with estimates of the strength of the relationship between the predictor (e.g., injustice) and collective action, potentially moderated by other variables (e.g., perceptions of injustice vs. emotional experience). All reported correlations were transformed back from z to r. 30

div.head: Four Motivations for Collective Action
div.p: Table 1 (first row) shows, in line with expectations, positive medium-sized effects for all four motivations for collective action. Extending these findings, the morality meta-analysis, showed a similar medium-sized effect. 31 Effect sizes were heterogeneous, reflecting in part the presumed diversity of cultures, contexts, and groups. For identity, effect sizes ranged from r = À.13 to r = .86; for morality, from r = .01 to r = .76; for injustice, from r = À.12 to r = .87, and for efficacy from r = À.46 to r = .85. The overall test for heterogeneity was significant for identity (Q E = 3783.30, df = 263, p , .0001; T 2 = .05 [.005]), morality (Q E = 997.58, df = 80, p , .0001; T 2 = .04 [.007]), injustice (Q E = 2836.44, df = 258, p , .0001; T 2 = .04 [.004]), and efficacy (Q E = 2893.33, df = 215, p , .0001; T 2 = .05 [.005]), which supports the use of random-effects models and suggests plenty of variance to be potentially explained by moderator variables.

We found little indication for a file-drawer problem. Three-parameter selection models, illustrated in Table 1 lower rows, were based on Vevea andWoods (2005; Table 1) and represented moderate one-tailed, severe one-tailed, moderate two-tailed, and severe two-tailed weight functions. Even under most extreme conditions (severe one-tailed selection models), average effects only dropped by r = .07. These sensitivity analyses suggest little movement of estimates when different weight functions are applied (also see Carter et al., 2019;McShane et al., 2016). P curve analyses, summarized in the online supplemental materials, corroborated this conclusion: We found evidence for right-skewness and no evidence for flatness (for more information see Harrer et al., 2019).

When further testing file-drawer problems with a combined trim-and-fill method (Duval & Tweedie, 2000a, 2000b), contourenhanced funnel plots (Peters et al., 2008), and added regression lines (Hilgard, 2016), we found that "missing studies" for all four predictors were in areas of statistical significance. Yet as illustrated in Figure 2a-2d, these missing studies were in areas of large positive effect sizes (Fisher's z transformed correlation coefficients larger than .5). Adding different types of regression lines to the data confirmed these analyses: We found a slight bias indicating that larger effects may have been missing from the database. 32 That being said, even when using the most conservative estimate of publication bias (adding a simple regression line), the mean effects all remained within the medium-sized range. As a final step, we tested a mixed-effects metaregression model which again showed some evidence that we were 29 This means that the number of effects differed per moderator analysis. For example, a study may have measured two different types of injustice: perceptions and feelings of unfairness. The study may have also included two different types of groups: a disadvantaged and an advantaged group acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged. This would mean that within one study we could code for four relevant correlations/effects. Depending on the research question we would average the effects differently. For example, for the overall effect of injustice on collective action, we would average all four correlations. If we were interested in moderation by type of injustice, we would average across the types of groups.

30 Prediction intervals can be computed with the R-Markdown output on OSF (Borenstein et al., 2017). 31 Note that we reversed the sign of the system justification effects as to make them comparable in meaning with the other moral motivations. 32 We also tested whether publication status (published yes or no) would influence the relationship between the four motivations and collective action. We did find indications that this was mostly the case (Identity: Q M = 13.327, p , .001, Morality: Q M = 1.791, p = .18, Injustice: Q M = 8.165, p = .004, Efficacy: observing slight publication bias, yet again in favor of larger effect studies (test for funnel plot asymmetry: Injustice: z = 2.16, p = .031; Injustice: z = 2.16, p = .03; Identity: z = 1.99, p = .046; Identity: z = 1.65, p = .099). Taken together, and considering our results in terms of three-parameter selection methods, p curve analyses, regression tests, the trim and fill, and the contour enhanced plots, we conclude that the literature we seek to synthesize seems quite healthy and robust.

div.head: Positive Interrelations Between the Four Motivations
div.p: A considerable subset of the samples in the database (n = 101) included effect size estimates from at least three predictors (n = 65 had identity, injustice, and efficacy; n = 36 had all four motivations) and provided sufficient information to estimate the effect size between these predictors. Within this reduced dataset, reported in Table 1 (second row), we found positive, mediumsized effects of the four motivations for collective action. This finding suggests that these subsets are fairly representative of the larger pool of samples. Table 2 shows positive, medium-to-strong effects between all predictors. In line with the dual chamber model, these ranged from r = .42 [.35, .48] between morality and identity, to r = .25 [.21, .29] between injustice and efficacy. Furthermore, two-stage structural equation modeling (Cheung, 2015) showed that each motivation indeed predicted collective action uniquely and positively: Identity, b = .24 [.17

div.head: Moderators About Motivation
div.p: We tested our predictions regarding the strongest motivations for collective action, with key findings, as well as heterogeneity indicators, summarized in Table 3.

div.head: Type of Identity
div.p: Replicating van Zomeren et al. (2008), type of identity moderated the relationship between identity and collective action, Q M = 21.23, p , .0001. As expected, politicized identity had a stronger effect on collective action, r = .45 [.41, .49] than identifying with a disadvantaged group, r = .34 [.30, .38]. This result means that the latter is a good motivation for collective action but that politicized identity has even stronger motivational potential. Confirming a recent trend in the literature, identifying with an opinion-based group produced a strong effect as well, r = .44 [.39, .49], on par with that of politicized identity. The "other" category produced weaker effects, r = .34 [.24, .42].

div.head: Type of Morality
div.p: Extending previous work, we found that type of morality moderated the effect size between morality and collective action, Q M = 7.259, p = .027. As expected, moral conviction was the strongest moral motivation for collective action, r = .40 [.35, .45], on par with violated beliefs or principles, r = .38 [.32, .44]. Further as expected, system justification demotivated collective action on average, r = À.26 [À.17, À.35].

div.head: Type of Injustice
div.p: Replicating van Zomeren et al. (2008), type of injustice moderated the relationship between injustice and collective action, Q M = 6.73, p = .009. As expected, feelings of injustice had a stronger effect on collective action, r = .39 [.37, .42], than perceptions of injustice, r = .33 [.30, .37]. Thus, it is likely that, although perceived injustice is a good motivation for collective action, feelings of injustice have even stronger motivational potential.

div.head: Type of Efficacy
div.p: Extending previous work, group efficacy beliefs/participative efficacy beliefs, r = .37 [.34, .40], did not differ from perceived effectiveness of the action/instrumentality of the outcome, r = .38 [.34, .43], Q M = .38, p = .945. Thus, in line with van Zomeren et al. (2008), we found little evidence that efficacy beliefs differed in terms of effect sizes.

div.head: Structural Constraints
