div.p: We tested our predictions regarding structural constraints. The key findings for cultural constraints are summarized in Table 4 and for other contextual constraints in Table 5. 34 In brief, we found support for small but theoretically relevant cultural constraints specifically to the identity motivation for collectivism and hierarchy values (and, conversely, an affording effect for egalitarian values); furthermore, the four motivations extended to members of advantaged groups and structural as well as incidental disadvantages. Thus, despite a pattern of small but theoretically relevant exceptions, the protester's heart seems to beat the same across the globe.

div.head: Cultural Constraints: Western Versus Non-Western
div.p: Comparing Western versus non-Western countries, Table 4 shows constraining effects for identity, Q M = 5.405, p = .020 but not for morality. 35 Specifically, we found that samples from non-Western countries (r = .31 [.23, .39]) yielded weaker effects than samples from Western countries (r = .41 [.38, .43]). 36

div.head: Cultural Constraints: Hofstede and Schwartz
div.p: In line with the above findings for identity, for Hofstede's (2001) collectivism dimension, Table 4 shows a constraining effect for only the identity motivation, Q M = 5.714, p = .017. For cultures with stronger collectivism, the relationship between identity and collective action was weaker, b = À.36 [À.006, À.065]. We did not find this constraining effect on the relationship between morality and collective action.

Adding to this pattern, Table 4 shows a similar constraint for hierarchy values: Here we found a weak constraint on the identity motivation, Q M = 3.700, p = .054 but again not for morality. In line with expectations, stronger hierarchy weakly constrained the relationship between identity and collective action, b = À.31 [À.63, .001]. Conversely, for egalitarian values, Table 4 shows a moderating effect for the identity motivation, Q M = 4.685, p = .03, such that stronger egalitarianism strengthened the relationship between identity and collective action, b = .31 [.59, .003]. 37

div.head: Exploring Other Cultural Findings
div.p: Table 4 summarizes the findings for all Hofstede and Schwartz indicators and all four motivations. Across the board, findings confirmed that the identity motivation for collective action was most likely to be constrained by cultural dimensions: Next to the reported moderation effects of collectivism, hierarchy, and egalitarianism, we also found nonpredicted effects of masculinity, Q M = 4.69, p = .03, and long-term orientation, Q M = 5.95, p = .015. Whereas masculinity strengthened the relationship between identity and collective action (b = .034 [.003, .065]), long-term orientation weakened it (b = À.038 [À.069, À.008]). 34 Tables 4 and5 also contain all nonsignificant test statistics not mentioned in the main text. The R-Markdown output on OSF contains all indexes of residual heterogeneity (Q E s).

35 Please note the relatively small cell size for morality in countries coded as non-Western. 36 Unexpectedly, we found constraining effects for injustice, Q M = 5.583, p = .018: Again, non-Western countries (r = .30 [.24, .36]) yielded weaker effects than in Western counties (r = .38 [.35, .40]). Yet because these findings did not replicate with the more specific cultural indicators, we refrain from interpreting this injustice effect (but potentially see Smith et al., 2018;Wong et al. (2008)). 37 Can this pattern be explained by mean-level cultural differences in the four motivations for collective action? This is unlikely because we did not observe any differences in mean levels for identity F(1, 195) = 0.01, p = .99, morality, F(1, 52) = 0.54, p = .47, injustice, F(1, 201) = 0.96, p = .33, or efficacy, F(1, 163) = 0.04, p = .84.

moderated by cultural dimensions and values. As such, we found little evidence that the protester's heart beats differently across the globe, with small but theoretically relevant exceptions for its identity chamber.foot_10

div.head: Contextual Constraints
div.p: Table 5 shows that all four motivations extended to solidaritybased forms of action. For both identity, Q M = 17.044, p , .001, as well as injustice, Q M = 4.52, p = .033, solidarity-based action produced even somewhat stronger effects of identity and injustice on collective action (Identity: r = .50 [.45, .55]; Injustice: r = .41 [.36, .45]) than other types of action did (Identity: r = .37 [.35, .40]; Injustice: r = .35 [.33, .38]). We did not observe any such effects for morality or efficacy, with correlations for both categories hovering around r = .37.

Table 5 further shows that the same pattern emerged for solidarity-based groups: For advantaged group members acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged, the mean effect size for identity, r = .49 [.40, .57], as well as injustice, r = .43 [.38, .48], was positive and strong-in fact again stronger than for other groups (Identity: Q M = 4.877, p = .027, r = .39 [.36, .41]; Injustice: Q M = 6.911, p = .009, r = .35 [.33, .38]). For morality and efficacy, these effects were not stronger compared with other groups but remained positive and strong.

Finally, Table 5 shows that structural or incidental disadvantage did not constrain effect sizes of the four motivations for collective action (neither for its dichotomous nor the continuous operationalization). Put differently, all four motivations in the dual chamber model of collective action extended to incidental and structural disadvantages.

div.head: Nonsubstantive and Explorative Moderators
div.p: All findings for this category of moderators can be found in the online supplemental materials (S1). In brief, and in line with van Zomeren et al. (2008), Table 6 shows little influence of age, gender, and causality on the effects of the four motivations on CA. Type of collective action (i.e., behavioral or nonbehavioral measures of collective action) across the board replicated previous findings that effect sizes tend to be smaller yet still sizable for behavioral measures. In a more exploratory fashion, some motivations for collective action seemed constrained by violent means of collective action yet seemed mainly unaffected by the online or offline nature of collective action.

div.head: Evaluating the Added Value of Morality in the Psychology of Collective Action
div.p: We used the subset of studies that reported all three or four predictors to fit meta-analytic structural equation models. 39 Because the input for these analyses is correlations, we model causal direction based on theoretical assumptions. Owing to strong heterogeneity indices in Stage I (.84-.93), we used a random-effects model (REM). We did not constrain diagonals and used 95% likelihoodbased CIs for the parameter estimates. We built up models stepby-step, testing whether assumptions for simpler models held when complexity (i.e., mediators or a new predictor) was added to the model. Full models are visualized in Figure 3a-3c, whereas the simpler models are visualized in figures in the online supplemental materials (together with statistics for direct and indirect effects as well as more detailed comparison to the full models). Unstandardized direct, indirect effects, and 95% CIs can be found in the respective figures.

Figure 3a shows support for the dual chamber model. We observed all hypothesized paths, and model fit was adequate, v 2 (1, N = 30186) = 84.55, p , .001; RMSEA = .053 [.044, .062], SRMR = .048 (both smaller than the recommended .08); CFI = .97 (above the .90 rule of thumb), TLI = .68 (which may be due to the TLI adjusting for the number of parameters fitted). Explained variance for collective action was 27%, for efficacy 28%, and for injustice 21%.

We then tested the original SIMCA (Figure 3b), which lacks morality. Replicating van Zomeren et al. (2008), findings supported this model, as we observed all hypothesized paths and model fit was adequate: v 2 (1, N = 30186) = 134.03, p , .001 (RMSEA = .066 [.057, .076]; SRMR = .084; CFI = .94, TLI = .63). Explained variance in collective action was 27%. We concluded that the dual chamber model fit the data somewhat better and also explained more variance across motivations and collective action than the original SIMCA. As such, the integration of morality into the model indeed adds value.

For the extended SIMCA (Figure 3c), which adds morality to the original SIMCA, we came to the same conclusion. We again observed all hypothesized paths and model fit was adequate: v 2 (2, N = 30186) = 97.39, p , .001 (RMSEA = .040 [.033, .047]; SRMR = .059; CFI = .96, TLI = .82). Explained variance in collective action was 27%, and the model also explained variance within identity (9%), efficacy (28%), and injustice (21%). As such, it outperforms the original SIMCA but does not outperform the dual chamber model. Indeed, the latter comparison is admittedly a very close call, given that they either add or integrate (and thus in either way include) morality: Both models have adequate fit and explain variance in collective action as well as its motivations. Although we do not want to attach too much weight to this, a statistical argument for favoring the dual chamber model is that, in terms of fit, v 2 = 84.55 (df = 1), this model fit the data slightly yet significantly better than the extended SIMCA, v 2 = 97.39 (df = 2), v 2 Diff = 12.84 (df = 1), p , .001. This statistical argument adds to our conceptual argument for a more integrative, rather than additive, approach.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: This quantitative research synthesis replicates previous work and breaks new theoretical ground by developing and testing an integrative, comprehensive, and potentially cross-cultural dual chamber model of collective action. Replicating previous meta-analytic conclusions (van Zomeren et al., 2008),we found that identity, injustice, and efficacy each showed unique and positive medium-sized relationships with collective action; that these motivations were all positively interrelated; and that the strongest motivations for collective action were politicized identification and the emotional experience of injustice (anger). Extending previous work, we found that morality, as a fourth motivation for collective action, showed a unique and positive medium-sized effect, as well as positive interrelationships with the other motivations (and in particular with identity); furthermore, we found that moral conviction ranked among the strongest motivations for collective action. Finally, meta-analytic structural equation modeling supported the dual chamber model. These findings support the proposed need for the integration of moral motivations into the psychology of collective action (e.g., Klandermans, 1997;Osborne et al., 2019;van Stekelenburg & Klandermans, 2009;van Zomeren et al., 2008) and confirm the centrality of morality in the protester's beating heart (e.g., van Zomeren et al., 2018).

This research synthesis further uncovered small but theoretically meaningful structural constraints (e.g., Hofstede, 1980;2001;Markus & Kitayama, 2010;Schwartz, 1992; see also Corcoran et al., 2011;van Zomeren, 2016b;van Zomeren & Louis, 2017). In terms of cultural constraints, we found that only the identity motivation was constrained in non-Western, more collectivistic countries, and in countries that value hierarchy more and egalitarianism less. We found little evidence for other contextual constraints: The four motivations extended to members of advantaged groups wanting to act in solidarity with disadvantaged groups and to structural as well as incidental disadvantages. Across the board, then, the protester's heart seems to beat rather similarly across the globe.

div.head: Theoretical Implications
div.p: We discuss four broad implications for the field of collective action and also discuss more specific implications for theory and research on (a) the protester's beating heart (i.e., identity and morality in the context of collective action), (b) injustice and efficacy as important downstream motivations for collective action, and (c) structural constraints to motivations for collective action.

div.head: Four Broad Implications
div.p: First, it seems the field was and still is on the right track, because we were able to replicate key findings from a previous meta-analysis (van Zomeren et al., 2008) with an independent, larger, and more diverse database. Moreover, we were able to rule out common concerns such as file-drawer problems and a strong overestimation of reported effect sizes. As such, the last decade of collective action research, despite its huge diversity in terms of contexts, groups, and cultures, confirms and strengthens previous conclusions. In an era of concerns about reproducibility (e.g., Open Science Collaboration, 2015) and generalizability (Yarkoni, 2019), this is a positive and welcome observation. The runaway horse seems healthy and alive and is still within our reigns. We suggest letting it run. Second, our research synthesis confirms and encourages the integration of insights from moral psychology with the psychology of collective action. Our findings confirm that (a) different moral variables can motivate collective action (e.g., moral conviction, perceived violation of moral beliefs or principles; Skitka, 2010) but also demotivate it (e.g., system justification; e.g., Jost et al., 2017); (b) moral conviction relates positively to the other motivations for collective action (in particular to identity; e.g., van Zomeren, 2013); and (c) this may explain why the four motivations can extend to members of other groups, such as advantaged groups, who act in solidarity with the disadvantaged (e.g., van Zomeren et al., 2018). Indeed, the dual chamber model's conceptualization of the protester's beating heart signifies how central moral motivation is to the psychology of collective action.

Third, the cultural constraints we identified for the identity chamber of the protester's beating heart were small yet theoretically meaningful. Based on the notion that morality and identity both serve to bind and obligate individuals into acting in concert (thus reflecting who "we" are and what "we stand for; Ellemers, 2017;van Zomeren et al., 2018), we hypothesized that collectivism (which binds and obligates individual in groups; Oyserman et al., 2002) and hierarchy values (that prioritize the status quo rather than social change) would constrain whether one would act collectively. Given that we found this relatively weak yet rather consistent broader pattern (including a constraining effect for non-Western countries, and the opposite pattern for countries with egalitarian values), this research synthesis offers a conceptual bridge between what binds and obligates individuals into groups at both the cultural and individual levels of analysis. Our findings offer a stepping stone for scholars to integrate key insights and concepts from cultural psychology into the psychology of collective action (Jasper, 2017;van Zomeren & Louis, 2017; see also Oyserman & Lauffer, 2002)-a promising, new, and largely untrodden avenue for theorizing and research.

Fourth and finally, the integration of morality into the protester's beating heart raises important questions about whether the definition of collective action itself may need an update. Because we are recommending further integration of the field with insights from moral and cultural psychology, it is critical that we can offer a definition that is based on state-of-the-art knowledge. Because our findings confirmed Table 6 Nonsubstantive and Exploratory Moderators for the Effects of Identity, Morality, Injustice, and Efficacy on Collective Action that the protester's heart has moral and identity chambers and seems to beat the same for members of a disadvantaged group or other group acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged (Curtin et al., 2016;Reimer et al., 2017;Saab et al., 2015;Subaši c et al., 2011;Thomas et al., 2020), morality should be as central as identity in any updated definition of collective action. Such a definition should thus not only refer to the identity management processes assumed in previous definitions (about who "we" are) but also refer to value protection processes associated with moral motivations for collective action (and thus about what "we" stand for). We therefore suggest an updated definition of collective action that fits with our portrayal of the protester's beating heart:

Collective action is any action that individuals undertake as psychological group members to improve the position of a relevant disadvantaged group as a whole, and/or to protect their or that group's values, moral principles, or ideology. 40 Obviously, this definition is open for future debate and amendments. 40 Some have gone even further (van Zomeren, 2016b) in arguing for opening up the definition for motivations that are not based in any group identity. We cannot evaluate this argument in the current research synthesis because we included only studies in line with previous, identity-based definitions.

div.head: Implications for Morality, Identity, and Collective Action
div.p: This research synthesis substantiates the central and positively related positions of morality and identity in the dual chamber model of collective action. Indeed, mean effect sizes for each were unique, positive, and medium-sized, with moral conviction and politicized identity ranking among the strongest motivations for collective action. This fits with the importance of understanding how people come to develop politicized identities (Duncan, 2012;Simon & Klandermans, 2001;Stürmer & Simon, 2004;Turner-Zwinkels et al., 2015, 2017). The dual chamber model suggests that morality may play an important part in this process of identity change of transformation (van Zomeren, 2013), with moral conviction being a catalyst for such change and system justification a barrier. Conversely, it is possible that developing a politicized identity offers fertile ground for developing moral conviction on specific issues (e.g., Leal et al., 2020). We thus need to learn more about how the protester's beating heart comes into being.

It is also essential for collective action research to identify the psychologically relevant group identity in a given context. This concept is not only important because politicized identities yield stronger motivational potential than nonpoliticized identities but also because we found that identification with opinion-based groups (e.g., Thomas & McGarty, 2009) produced effect sizes on par with those of politicized identity. This finding is interesting because such group identities revolve around an opinion (e.g., against poverty) rather than around an organization (e.g., Greenpeace); yet in either case, the relevant identity may, implicitly or explicitly, already include a moral aspect. It is unclear at present, however, what the specific "active ingredient" is-moral conviction (van Zomeren et al., 2011;van Zomeren, Leach, & Spears, 2012), perceived violation of moral beliefs of principles (Kutlaca et al., 2019;Mazzoni et al., 2015), moral identity content (Turner-Zwinkels et al., 2017), moral obligation (Sabucedo et al., 2018), or inner obligation (Stürmer & Simon, 2004). We thus need to learn more about the psychological anatomy of this part of the protester's beating heart.

Finally, the dual chamber model implies that it is important to improve our understanding and conceptualization of how individuals and groups are embedded in systems that they sometimes seek to defend (Jost et al., 2019;Owuamalam et al., 2018). Indeed, our research synthesis included the recent trend to include system justification, as an ideological motivation to protect such a broader system, in the study of collective action. We grouped system justification under the umbrella of moral motivations for collective action based on its grounding in ideology (Jost et al., 2017), a decision supported by recent findings that system justification can motivate collective action to protect the system (Osborne et al., 2019). But other work might not conceptually include system justification as part of the moral domain (e.g., Skitka et al., 2017) or has not found empirical traces of it as part of people's everyday experiences of morality (Hofmann et al., 2014). As such, our decision is open for future debate and amendments, and offers a clear avenue for theorizing and focused research on the moral or nonmoral nature of the relationship between system justification and collective action.

div.head: Implications for Injustice, Efficacy, and Collective Action
div.p: The dual chamber model conceptualizes the injustice and efficacy motivations as unique motivations for collective action, and as downstream motivational consequences of the protester's heart (that help one understand and deal with the group's situation). Our findings indeed show positive relationships with the moral-identity chambers of the protester's heart, while also showing that their own interrelationship reflects the weakest link. These associations are consistent with previous meta-analytic observations (van Zomeren et al., 2008) and provide some support for the portrayals of the protester as "passionate responders" and "cold calculators" as two different ways to understand and deal with the group situation (van Zomeren, Leach, & Spears, 2012). Indeed, the injustice and efficacy motivations are often based on "trigger events" (e.g., media coverage of an instance of police brutality) that individuals, as cultural beings, seek to understand and deal with. Although the protester's beating heart is key to understanding collective action, the situational triggers that directly affect the bloodstream are equally important to understand. Specifically, our findings replicated the key insight that felt injustice (e.g., anger) yields stronger motivational power than perceived injustice. This result confirms that anger is a potentially powerful response to threats or violations of one's identity or morals; as unlike most other negative emotions, it yields a strong approach motivation (Carver & Harmon-Jones, 2009;Frijda, 1986;Lazarus, 1991; see also Goldenberg et al., 2016;Mackie & Smith, 2002;van Zomeren, 2013). Furthermore, our findings replicated the key insight that efficacy yields strong motivational power, either in terms of group/participative efficacy beliefs or perceived effectiveness. These reflect different ways of understanding the group's situation: as an agentic team player (e.g., Cohen-Chen & Van Zomeren, 2018); or as a cold, individualistic calculator of costs and benefits (Klandermans, 1984;Olson, 1968;Simon et al., 1998). As such, and just like anger, they can be situationally triggered (Stürmer & Simon, 2004;van Zomeren, Leach, & Spears, 2012). 41

div.head: Implications for Theory and Research on Structural Constraints
div.p: Although our research synthesis found evidence for small structural constraints, the broader pattern was that the dual chamber model seems to have cross-cultural potential. For one, we found that the four motivations for collective action extended to members of other groups acting in solidarity with the disadvantaged, and to structural as well as incidental disadvantages. This likely reflects that collective action research perhaps too often studies why people engage in collective action under conditions already favorable to collective action (van Zomeren, 2016b), which may severely restrict structural variance, and further paint a rather overoptimistic picture of collective action. Indeed, McAdam and Boudet (2012) longitudinally found that in many contexts where collective action could have been expected, it simply did not materialize. We thus need a better understanding of the structural conditions under which motivations for collective action arise (e.g., McAdam & Boudet, 2012;van Zomeren, 2016a). 42 As for cultural constraints, the dual chamber model offers a conceptual bridge between cultural psychology and the psychology of collective action. Indeed, our findings suggest that theoretical integration of cultural constraints is a promising yet challenging path (Jasper, 2017;van Zomeren & Louis, 2017; see also Smith et al., 2013;Vignoles et al., 2016): We specifically found that countries that are non-Western, more collectivist, and value hierarchy more and egalitarianism less yielded small but meaningful constraints on the identity motivation for collective action. We interpret these findings in terms of cross-cultural variance in how binding and obligating the relevant group identities are (which should be stronger in non-Western, collectivist countries) but also how binding and obligating the broader system is in which this group is embedded (which should be stronger in countries where hierarchy is valued more and egalitarianism less). To illustrate, Van Zomeren et al. (2016) surveyed Indonesian ethnic minority members about ethnic discrimination in their country, which ranks high on collectivism as well as hierarchy values, and found, in two separate studies, rather rare null correlations between ethnic minority group identification and willingness to engage in collective action. We thus explain such findings in terms of cultural norms that embed the group in the broader (hierarchical) system. 43 Note that this explanation assumes a conceptualization of culture as shared norms that people internalize or otherwise conform to (e.g., Hofstede, 1980Hofstede, , 2001;;Markus & Kitayama, 2010). As Oyserman and Lauffer (2002, p. 163) put it, people are assumed to "make sense of things using a culture-specific scaffolding" and in the context of collective action, such sense-making includes who "we" are and what "we" stand for. Making this assumption explicit is important because it connects the country-level conceptualizations of culture (and country-level data) we used in the research synthesis with the psychological level of analysis used in studies of collective action. As such, we assumed that cultural dimensions and values from a particular country would trickle down to the samples associated with that same country. This idea may explain, in part at least, why the cultural constraints we identified were small in size: Presumably, if we could have known the "true" cultural composition of the sample (rather than the country in which it was conducted), we might have seen stronger constraining effects. Future research should therefore not only rely on countrylevel indicators of culture but where possible, also on its psychological indicators.

Finally, our findings imply that there may be more cultural variance to explore, offering another step toward an exciting research agenda on the cultural psychology of collective action (e.g., van Zomeren & Louis, 2017). Indeed, we observed several unpredicted but interesting cultural constraints: For example-again, only for identity-we found effects for masculinity (i.e., valuing competitiveness; with weaker masculinity constraining identity effects) and long-term orientation (i.e., foregoing short-term outcomes; with longer-term orientation constraining identity effects). We interpret these findings as implying that valuing competitiveness and short-term outcomes means a stronger preference for collective action to achieve such goals. Future theory and research can explore such findings in more detail and test whether and how theoretically relevant cultural dimensions and values affect the motivations for collective action at both the cultural and individual level (e.g., Fischer, 2009;Hofstede, 1980Hofstede, , 2001;;Markus & Kitayama, 2010;Schwartz, 1992).

div.head: Practical Implications and Caveats
div.p: Previous practical recommendations focused on the importance of social identity, as well as injustice and efficacy, for motivating individuals for collective action; specifically, the main emphasis was on building a politicized identity (e.g., Stürmer & Simon, 2004). The main changes we suggest to these practical recommendations are to emphasize the joint importance of morality and identity and to broaden the emphasis on targeting not just politicized but also opinion-based identities and the relevant moral convictions these may reflect. In other words, we recommend practitioners use narratives about who "we" are and what "we" stand for. If such framing psychologically (and culturally) resonates with individuals (Oyserman & Lauffer, 2002); our findings imply that this is likely to stimulate (other motivations for) collective action (but see Kleres & Wettergren, 2017), or to stimulate people's readiness to act in response to situational triggers of injustice and efficacy. Furthermore, it is important to consider what specific types of identity, morality, injustice, and efficacy should be targeted in a given collective action context. Our findings suggest, for example, that they should target politicized or opinion-based group identities, stronger moral convictions, anger, group and participative efficacy beliefs, and perceived effectiveness, to best motivate individuals for collective action.

Some caution is warranted in considering whether collective action is actually a good or desirable thing. Although this concept often refers to mostly peaceful attempts to change the world for what people believe is the better, 44 it cannot be completely valuefree or objective (Gergen, 1973) because it requires assumptions about what counts as "better" (also see Kreienkamp et al., 2020). Indeed, most studies of collective action focus on liberal goals and participant samples, and thus also on morals and social movements 42 Theories of goal pursuit and obstruction (e.g., De Lemus et al., 2017;Leander et al., 2019Leander et al., , 2020;;Stollberg et al., 2017) argue that different means exist within a given situation to fulfill a currently active goal (Kruglanski et al., 2002). As such, cultural norms play an important part in determining what constitutes viable goals to achieve through collective action.

43 This may also explain why we did not find such cultural constraints for morality, as the core of such constraints does not lie in what "we" stand for, but whether this "we" is entrenched in a broader "us." 44 A similar observation can be made for the case of violent collective action. Most studies on collective action focus on so-called normative collective action (Tausch et al., 2011;Wright et al., 1990), which means the action would fall within societal norms of what is considered acceptable and appropriate (e.g., signing a petition, joining a peaceful demonstration). Whereas other work has focused on nonnormative collective action (e.g., Becker et al., 2011;Tausch et al., 2011), in practice it is often difficult to differentiate between what the protesters believe to be normative and what society finds acceptable (e.g., a strike of farmers occupying highways with their big machinery); which society might disapprove of if it takes too long, but the farmers themselves may feel this is perfectly acceptable and justified. This is different, however, for violent collective actions, such as riots, or acts of sabotage, or even terrorism, which are often consensually considered as non-normative (Piven & Cloward, 1977). Against this backdrop, we found that, when testing for moderations by violent collective action in our database, the same motivations predicted violent collective action, although for some in a somewhat weaker way.

that many would consider politically left-wing (Duarte et al., 2015). With this comes a notion of social change as progressive social change (e.g., increasing equal rights) and collective action as mostly peaceful and nonharmful public manifestations of those who seek a better world (Górska et al., 2017). In fact, relatively few studies have focused on conservatives' collective action or on the protection of the system as the goal of such action (rather than social change). This gap raises the question as to whether the dual chamber model would apply to such action. As the few studies that have done so indeed seem to suggest that the same motivations apply (Jost et al., 2017;Milesi & Alberici, 2018), we would not be surprised to find that although liberal and conservative protesters may have different ideas about what is right and wrong, their hearts may, perhaps, not beat so differently.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: This quantitative research synthesis has at least four limitations. First, we cannot control which contexts researchers (decided to) study, and hence our quantitative research synthesis is bounded to structural conditions already favorable to collective action. As such, we can interpret the effects of the identity, morality, injustice, and efficacy motivations when collective action is already likely or ongoing, but we need to be cautious in extending this to conditions under which structural conditions are less favorable.

Second, although we consistently conceptualized motivations for collective action as predictors of such action, a limitation of the correlational nature of the data is that the direction of causality may also be possible. We note, however, that we replicated Van Zomeren et al.'s (2008) finding that studies that allowed for causal interpretation of the effects did not show larger or smaller effect sizes than studies that did not allow such causal interpretations (although cell sizes were small for causal effects). Like van Zomeren et al. (2008), we interpret this finding to mean that the direction of causality seems to flow from and in both directions with equal strength and hence does not invalidate our interpretation of our findings. It is up to future longitudinal or experimental studies to test whether this is indeed the case. 45Third, sample sizes for the morality meta-analysis in particular, and for non-Western cultures more generally, were relatively small. This limitation directly derives from the state of the literature we synthesized, in which morality is only a recent focus of attention and most research is still conducted with Western samples. Across the board, however, our analyses showed converging patterns in line with the literature, suggesting this imbalance may not be a threat to the validity of our findings.

Fourth, although the mean effects of the four motivations on collective action were sizable, in line with predictions, and obtained despite much variance in groups, samples, methods, and contexts, a critic might argue that the dual chamber model does not yet explain this variance very well. We interpret this more positively, however, namely as offering scope for future theorizing and research. The current research synthesis reflects and documents the work in progress that the literature we synthesized represents, and the next step indeed is theoretically to better explain the contextual variance around the four motivations for collective action, and then systematically test such explanations in future research.

div.head: Directions for Future Research
div.p: We recommend at least four avenues for future research. First, we need to better understand psychological change over time (e.g., in terms of increased or decreased motivations for collective action). Although some studies have looked at the psychological consequences of participating in collective action (e.g., Leal et al., 2020;Thomas et al., 2020), the processes through which such psychological change occur are not yet clearly understood (e.g., Turner-Zwinkels et al., 2015). Some models include predictions about such consequences (e.g., Becker & Tausch, 2015;van Zomeren et al., 2012), but these typically entail rather simplistic positive feedback loops from collective action to specific motivations for collective action, suggesting that participating in such action may politicize (identity), moralize (morality), enrage (injustice/anger), and empower (efficacy). Such exclusively positive feedback loops, however, seem somewhat unrealistic. We need to better understand such motivational but also potential null or demotivational effects on sustained participation.

Second, we recommend developing theories and studying the difference between motivation and actual behavior more systematically. van Zomeren et al. (2008) observed that most studies on collective action used proxy measures of collective action, such as intentions or support for collective action, rather than measures of actual behavior-and it is no different in the current database, more than ten years later. Behavioral measures yielded smaller effect sizes than proxy measures, but future research should assess what this difference actually means. It may mean, for one, that the use of proxy measures inflated effect sizes, as people can more easily say that they want to engage in collective action than they would actually do so in practice. This would imply proxies are "cheap talk" measures and thus researchers should use behavioral measures. A second possibility is that behavioral measures, unlike proxy measures, tap into a broader process that does not only include motivation but also the individual's decision process that also involves reasons for not acting (e.g., Klandermans, 1984;Klandermans & Van Stekelenburg, 2014;Oegema & Klandermans, 1994). This possibility would suggest that either effect size is meaningful in its own way (reflecting motivation, or motivation coupled with decision-making). Future research needs to examine this difference in more detail.

Third, future research can seek to further extend and apply the dual chamber model to other actors and possibly to other goals. For instance, Klavina and van Zomeren (2018) recently found that the four motivations could even be applied to third groups, which are groups that may perhaps find themselves in a disadvantaged position in the future (also see Thomas et al., 2020). In terms of different goals, the four motivations may extend to collective action to maintain the status quo, rather than to change it (Osborne et al., 2019). Such a quest for a broader application of the dual chamber model may suggest that the four motivations may perhaps not be limited to predicting collective action as currently defined (see van Zomeren, 2016b). Exploring such questions will help to establish fruitful links with other literatures and disciplines interested in broader manifestations of political action, such as sociology and political science (e.g., Green & Gerber, 2019).

Finally, future research can focus on the motivational power of interpersonal relationships and embeddedness in social networks (Van Zomeren, 2016a). The social identity approach has been a dominant influence in this literature for the last three decades, and as a result, the focus has been on individuals who act as psychological group members (see McGarty et al., 2009; for a critique). As much as individuals are cultural, moral, and group beings, individuals are also relational beings (van Zomeren, 2016a) who are motivated to manage their interpersonal relationships and networks, such as in the case of activists who ask their activist friends to join collective action (e.g., Klandermans et al., 2008). At present, however, there is no clear psychological explanation for why such embeddedness should motivate collective action. The recent trend toward studying how intra-and intergroup contact influences collective action might be helpful (e.g., Cakal et al., 2011;Dixon et al., 2015Dixon et al., , 2017;;Reimer et al., 2017), as this may force the field to consider the protester as a manager of interpersonal relationships as well.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: This article has synthesized a recent explosion of sociopsychological theorizing and research on collective action across very different groups, contexts, and cultures. Our research synthesis replicated previous meta-analytic work and breaks new theoretical ground by developing and substantiating an integrative, comprehensive, and potentially cross-cultural dual chamber model of collective action. This model paints a portrait of the protester's beating heart as having morality and identity chambers, which, to continue the metaphor, collaborate to oxygenate the blood pumped around the body, thus stimulating the injustice and efficacy motivations for collective action. Our findings confirm the need and value of integrating these four unique yet interrelated motivations and offer a new conceptual bridge for theorizing about structural (i.e., cultural and other contextual) constraints to these motivations. Our hope is that this research synthesis inspires collective action scholars to take theory and research to a next level of theoretical integration (e.g., seeking bridges with moral and cultural psychology, as well as sociology and political science), and toward innovative and exciting avenues of future research, as to better understand when and why people engage in collective action across the globe.

The moral and injustice motivations are conceptually distinct, although perceived injustices may sometimes have moral connotations(Folger, 1987). Indeed, perceiving collective disadvantage as unfair does not necessarily imply that one's morals are violated (e.g.,van Zomeren, 2013), perceiving something as immoral can affect whether it is perceived as unfair or fair(Skitka, 2010), and one can be aware of social inequality yet consider this a morally acceptable, or even good, part of the system or social structure (e.g.,Jost et al., 2017), and hence do not perceive it as unfair.

All motivations for collective action imply a goal that collective action can fulfill. As such, it is not necessarily moral conviction per se that motivates participation in Black Lives Matter protests, but the specific moral conviction relevant in this context (e.g., against racism) and that this movement stands and acts for.COLLECTIVE ACTION

In Mummendey et al.'s (1999) study of East Germans after the Wall fell, perceived stability was not related to motivation for collective action. InVan Zomeren et al.'s (2016) study of Indonesian ethnic minority group members, perceived stability, legitimacy, and impermeability all correlated positively, rather than negatively, with collective action intentions.

This pertains to whatKlandermans (2004, p. 1) coined the supply (rather than demand) side of protest: "Demand refers to the potential in a society for protest; supply refers, on the other hand, to the opportunities staged by organizers to protest," and to what others call political opportunity structures (e.g.,Rootes, 1999). Because the collective action literature rarely focused on this type of contextual variables, it is not included in this quantitative research synthesis.COLLECTIVE ACTION

We provide a brief section on non-substantial and explorative moderators (e.g., participant age, online vs. offline collective action, gender, violent vs. non-violent, or type of method), with all details reported in Table6and in the in online supplemental materials.
Note that studies on collective action are always set within a particular
We also used an "other" category, which in the end consisted of dual identity, outgroup identity, online identity, and identity fusion (all when referred to as such).

We included these codings to explore questions such as: Do the four motivations extend to violent as well as non-violent collective action? And do they extend to online as well as offline forms of collective action? COLLECTIVE ACTION
Fit statistics were not available, because this model was saturated.
As Table4shows, we did not see the same pattern for Hofstede's power distance dimension or the Schwartz harmony value.
We also tested several other models, reported in the online supplemental materials. COLLECTIVE ACTION

Our findings showed positive correlations between efficacy and the dual chambers of the protester's beating heart. This confirms previous meta-analytic findings for identity and extends them for morality.
Reassuringly, recent studies seem to support these assumptions (e.g.,Leal et al., 2020;Thomas et al., 2020).
